Yes, the location of a golf course has a significant impact on the outcome of the PGA Championship. Here are a few reasons:

1. Course Design: The design of a golf course can make it more or less challenging for players. For example, some courses may have narrow fairways, numerous hazards, or sloping greens that require a great deal of skill to navigate. A player's ability to adjust to the course design is critical to success in the championship.

2. Climate: The climate can also have a big impact on the outcome of the tournament. If a course is located in an area known for high winds or sudden weather changes, players will need to adjust their strategies accordingly. Players may need to adapt their shots to account for the wind or may need to change their clubs depending on the weather.

3. Altitude: The altitude of a course can also impact how the ball travels through the air. In general, lower altitude courses tend to favor players who can hit the ball farther, while higher altitude courses tend to level the playing field. Players who are used to playing at a particular altitude may struggle to adjust to a course at a different altitude.

4. Grass Types: The type of grass used on a course can also affect a player's game. Some players may be used to playing on bent grass, while others may be more comfortable playing on Bermuda grass. Different grasses can have varying speeds and contours, which can impact the players' putts and other shots.

All of these factors can combine to impact the outcome of the PGA Championship. A player who excels at a particular type of course or in certain weather conditions may struggle if the course doesn't suit their strengths. Ultimately, the location of the course can greatly impact which player is most likely to come out on top.
